adjectives.description: expendable (comparative more expendable, superlative most expendable)

entries.meaning: Able to be expended; not inexhaustible.
examples: Oil and other expendable resources are frequently the subject of military disputes.

entries.meaning: Designed for a single use; not reusable.
examples: The anti-aircraft rocket is fired from an expendable launch platform.

entries.meaning: Not essential or mandatory in order to achieve a goal.
examples: The research department was deemed expendable, and its funding was not renewed.

entries.meaning: Regarded as not worth preserving or saving; able to be sacrificed.
examples: In the internecine rivalries of large corporations, whole departments may become expendable in the execution of one executive's power play.

entries.meaning: An expendable person or object; usually used in the plural.
examples: Private Johnson was afraid the Lieutenant considered him an expendable, since he was always picked as point man.
